facts.text: Two appeals arise out of two assessment orders made under the Income-tax Act, 1922, for the years 1945-46 and 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: These are two appeals arising out of two assessment orders made under the Income-tax Act, 1922, respectively for the years 1945-46 and 1947-48.

facts.text: In each assessment case there was a reference of certain questions to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh under section 66 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In each assessment case there was a reference of certain questions to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh under section 66 of the Act and the present appeals are against the High Courts answers to these questions.

facts.text: The assessee is a trader carrying on two businesses, namely manihari general merchandise and bidis.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a trader carrying on two businesses, namely manihari  general merchandise  and bidis.

facts.text: The assessee had certain income from property but this income is not concerned in these appeals.

anchor.surface_text: He had also certain income from property but with this income we are number companycerned in these appeals.

facts.text: For each of the assessment years concerned, the assessee submitted a return.

anchor.surface_text: For each of the assessment years companycerned, the assessee had submitted a return

facts.text: Assessee's accounts were not found complete and reliable.

anchor.surface_text: but as his accounts were number found companyplete and reliable,

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed the gross profits of the businesses on the basis of certain percentages of the total sales fixed by estimates.

anchor.surface_text: the Income-tax officer had assessed the gross profits of the businesses on the basis of certain percentages of the total sales which had also to be fixed by estimates.

facts.text: No question arises in these appeals as to the correctness of these assessments.

anchor.surface_text: No question arises in these appeals as to the companyrectness of these assessments.

facts.text: While dealing with the assessment for the year 1948-49, the Income-tax Officer noticed various credit entries in the assessee's books of account which escaped attention earlier.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, while dealing with the assessment for the year 1948-49, the Income-tax Officer numbericed various credit entries in the assessees books of account which had all escaped his attention at the time of the assessment for the years 1945-46 and 1947-48 earlier mentioned.

facts.text: Credit entry in Gold Khata for Rs. 41,300 in 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: These entries were as follows 1945-46 Rs. Rs.  i  Gold Khata 41,300

facts.text: Credit entry in Ghar Khata for Rs. 33,000 in 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: ii  Ghar Khata 33,000

facts.text: Credit entry in Mohammad Islam Khata for Rs. 10,000 in 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: iii  Mohammad Islam Khata 10,000

facts.text: Credit entry in Muslim Bi Khata for Rs. 11,000 in 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: iv  Muslim Bi Khata 11,000 Total 95,300

facts.text: Credit entry in Ghar Khata under sale of ornaments for Rs. 19,575 in 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: 1947-48  i  Ghar Khata credit under sale of ornaments 19,575

facts.text: Credit entry in Yakub Manihar account as loan for Rs. 20,000 in 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: ii  Yakub Manihar account Loan from Yakub Manihar 20,000 Total 39,575

facts.text: Income-tax Officer re-opened the assessments with sanction of the Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer thereupon, with the sanction of the Commissioner of Income-tax, re-opened the assessments in respect of these years

facts.text: Income-tax Officer gave assessee full opportunity to explain the nature of these entries and made fresh assessments under section 34 adding Rs. 95,300 for 1945-46 and Rs. 39,575 for 1947-48 as income.

anchor.surface_text: and after giving the assessee full opportunity to explain the nature of these entries made fresh assessments under section 34. In the fresh assessments he added to the previously estimated incomes the said sum of Rs. 95,300 in respect of the year 1945-46 and the said sum of Rs. 39,575 in respect of the year 1947-48,

facts.text: Assessee contended that the credit entries did not represent income.

anchor.surface_text: as he was unable to accept the explanation offered by the assessee in support of his companytention that the credit entries did number represent income.

facts.text: Assessee appealed fresh assessments to Appellate Assistant Commissioner but appeals unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed against these fresh assessments to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner but the appeals were unsuccessful.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Income-tax Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: He then appealed to the Income-tax Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal found assessee's explanation for Rs. 33,000 Ghar Khata and Rs. 10,000 Muhammad Islam Khata acceptable and ordered deletion from 1945-46 assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found the assessees explanation with regard to the said entries for the amounts of Rs. 33,000 and Rs. 10,000 under the heads Ghar Khata and Muhammad Islam Khata respectively, acceptable and ordered their deletion from the assessment for the year 1945-46,

facts.text: Tribunal otherwise maintained the orders of the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: but otherwise maintained the orders of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: High Court ordered reference under section 66(2) at instance of assessee; Tribunal referred six questions in each case.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, under the orders of the High Court under section 66 2  of the Act made at the instance of the assessee, the Tribunal framed six questions in each of the assessment cases and referred them to the High Court for its decision.

facts.text: High Court answered the questions against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: These questions were answered by the high Court against the assessee and hence, the present appeals by the assessee.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

It is well established that the onus of proving the source of a sum of money found to have been received by the assessee is on him.

issues.text: Whether the burden of proving the source of the cash credits is on the assessee ?

anchor.surface_text: The first question that arises for discussion is question No.4, which was in these terms Whether the burden of proving the source of the cash credits is on the assessee ? It seems to us that the answer to this question must be in the affirmative and that is how it was answered by the High Court.

issues.text: If so, then whether in the absence of satisfactory proof as to the source of credits the inference of the Tribunal that these credits are the assessees income from some undisclosed sources is an inference of fact or an inference of law ?

anchor.surface_text: We come to question No.5, which is as follows If so, then whether in the absence of satisfactory proof as to the source of credits the inference of the Tribunal that these credits are the assessees income from some undisclosed sources is an inference of fact or an inference of law ? We confess we find it difficult to see the point of this question.

issues.text: Whether having regard to the fact that the Income-tax Officer has assessed the income on a percentage basis, he was justified in treating the said sums of Rs. 41,300 and Rs. 11,000 as profits from an undisclosed source ?

anchor.surface_text: We have now to deal with the last question, question No.6, which, as framed in the case for the assessment year 1945-46, is set out below Whether having regard to the fact that the Income-tax Officer has assessed the income on a percentage basis, he was justified in treating the said sums of Rs. 41,300 and Rs. 11,000 as profits from an undisclosed source ?

anchor.surface_text: Questions can be referred under section 66 of the Act when they are questions of law which arise out of the facts found by the Tribunal and which the Tribunal is said to have answered erroneously thereby unlawfully imposing a burden of tax on an assessee. On questions of fact, the Tribunal is the final authority and such questions cannot be referred to a High Court for its decision.

holdings.text: The answer to question No.4 must be in the affirmative: the burden of proving the source of the cash credits is on the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the burden of proving the source of the cash credits is on the assessee ? It seems to us that the answer to this question must be in the affirmative and that is how it was answered by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well established that onus is on assessee to prove source or that receipt not income or exempt; ITO entitled to treat as taxable otherwise; cites A. Govindarajulu Mudaliar.

holdings.text: It is well established that the onus of proving the source of a sum of money found to have been received by the assessee is on him.

anchor.surface_text: It is well established that the onus of proving the source of a sum of money found to have been received by the assessee is on him. If he disputes liability for tax, it is for him to show either that the receipt was number income or that if it was, it was exempt from taxation under the provisions of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of established principle with further explanation on consequences of failure to prove.

holdings.text: A question whether the inference drawn by the Tribunal is one of fact or law cannot be referred under section 66.

anchor.surface_text: Questions can be referred under section 66 of the Act when they are questions of law which arise out of the facts found by the Tribunal and which the Tribunal is said to have answered erroneously thereby unlawfully imposing a burden of tax on an assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Such question does not arise from Tribunal's decision; Tribunal final on facts; referable only if law arising from facts and erroneous.

holdings.text: On questions of fact, the Tribunal is the final authority and such questions cannot be referred to a High Court for its decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme under s66 limits reference to questions of law from Tribunal findings.

holdings.text: The reason of double taxation is fallacious; no double taxation when income treated as from undisclosed source distinct from previously assessed disclosed source.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisclosed source income separate; not same as previously estimated business income.

holdings.text: Taxing authorities not precluded from treating credit entries as income from undisclosed sources despite computing business income on percentage basis.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it cannot be said that the taxing authorities were precluded from treating the amounts of the credit entries as income from undisclosed sources simply because the entries appear in the books of a business whose income they had previously companyputed on a percentage basis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Source determined on all facts, independent of estimation method for disclosed business; rejects suggestion of automatic preclusion.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the burden of proving the source of the cash credits is on the assessee ? It seems to us that the answer to this question must be in the affirmative and that is how it was answered by the High Court.
These appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

It is well established that the onus of proving the source of a sum of money found to have been received by the assessee is on him. If he disputes liability for tax, it is for him to show either that the receipt was number income or that if it was, it was exempt from taxation under the provisions of the Act.
These appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.
